item.title: Vietnam’s Coffee Crop Set for Higher Yields on Ample Rains
item.description: Vietnam’s coffee crop is off to a strong start as heavy rainfall bolstered the supply outlook, which could put further pressure on global prices that are near a seven-month low.
item.dc:creator: Anuradha Raghu, Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen

media:content.media:description: A worker harvests coffee cherries in Dak Lak province, Vietnam.

item.title: De Beers Draws Interest From Ex-CEOs as Anglo Starts Sale
item.description: Anglo American Plc is about to begin a formal sales process for De Beers, after receiving indications of interest from potential buyers that include two former chief executives of the iconic diamond miner.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Biesheuvel, Dinesh Nair

media:content.media:description: Duncan Wanblad Photographer: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg

item.title: Iran Escalates IAEA Feud After ‘Slanderous’ Espionage Assertion
item.description: Iran is escalating its fight with the United Nations nuclear watchdog by accusing its inspectors of slander and presenting sloppy evidence, according to a legal brief circulated among diplomats days before a key meeting in Vienna.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: The Iranian national flag outside the International Atomic Energy Agency headquarters in Vienna.

item.title: Swiss Chocolate Stocks Diverge as Costly Cocoa Takes Toll
item.description: Shares in two of Switzerland’s biggest chocolatiers are on markedly different courses this year as soaring cocoa prices prove a tougher obstacle for one than they do for the other.
item.dc:creator: Allegra Catelli, Lisa Pham

media:content.media:description: Lindt Dubai Chocolate

item.title: Long-Dated Bonds Are Tough Sell to Investors These Days
item.description: BlackRock and DoubleLine are among the firms wary about long-dated government debt.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill, Ruth Carson, Phil Serafino

item.title: Musk Seeks to ‘Kill’ Tax Bill as Trump, Senate Talk SALT
item.description: Elon Musk is attempting to block President Donald Trump’s tax bill after failing to convince Republican lawmakers to preserve electric vehicle tax credits in the legislation. Meanwhile, Donald Trump and Republican senators discussed ways to scale back the $40,000 state and local tax deduction cap in the House version of the bill. Kevin Whitelaw reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Trump Broadcasts Putin Warning, Musk Seeks to ‘Kill’ Tax Bill | Bloomberg The Pulse 06/05
item.description:
Donald Trump broadcast Vladimir Putin’s warning that he’ll retaliate against Ukraine for its recent stunning drone strikes deep inside Russian territory, the clearest signal yet that the US president’s peace efforts have stalled. Meanwhile Elon Musk is on a mission to block President Donald Trump’s tax bill after he tried — and failed — to convince Republican lawmakers to preserve valuable tax credits for electric vehicles in the legislation, according to a person familiar with the matter.
Today's guests: Sören Radde, Point72 European Economic Research Head, Didier Stoessel, PPF CIO & Incoming Co-CEO, Gabriel Caillaux, General Atlantic Head of Climate, Andrew Forrest, Fortescue Executive Chairman & Minderoo Foundation Founder (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fortescue's Forrest on Tariffs, Deep-Sea Mining 'Farce'
item.description: President Trump's tariffs are "not working", according to Australian mining executive Andrew Forrest, who has called for a return to free trade. Forrest, the executive chairman of Fortescue and founder of the Minderoo Foundation, has also described the rules around deep-sea mining as a "farce", as he turns his attention to ocean conservation. Forrest says if you preserve 30% of the ocean, you can fish the remaining 70% "forever", comparing this to "a bank account that never runs out". Forrest joined Francine Lacqua on "The Pulse". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Private Equity Faces ‘Bad Vintage Assets’: Sixth Street
item.description: Sixth Street’s co-chief investment officer Julian Salisbury, says there’s “incredible pressure” from investors to return capital as private equity deals with “a lot of bad vintage assets.” He speaks with Bloomberg’s Dani Burger on the sidelines of the SuperReturn Conference in Berlin.

item.title: Bridgestone Halts Liberia Rubber Purchases as Prices Raised
item.description: Firestone Liberia LLC has halted rubber purchases from farmers after the government raised the price paid to growers.
item.dc:creator: Festus Poquie

media:content.media:description: Workers pack rubber into a truck on the Firestone campus in Harbel, Liberia.

item.title: Treasury Rally Eases as Investors Cautious on Jobs and Outlook
item.description: A rally in US Treasuries steadied, with investors cautious ahead of Friday’s jobs report and slightly paring bets on interest-rate cuts from the Federal Reserve.
item.dc:creator: Aline Oyamada

item.title: US Stock Futures Waver as Jobs Data Looms Ahead: Markets Wrap
item.description: US equity futures struggled for direction as investors awaited Friday’s payrolls report, following a series of data releases that offered varied signals on the health of the economy. In Europe, the central bank will almost certainly lower interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Sagarika Jaisinghani

media:content.media:description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Katie Greifeld, David Gura, Emily Graffeo.

item.title: Russia’s Crude Production Remained Below OPEC+ Target in May
item.description: Russia’s data show the nation kept its crude oil production below its OPEC+ target in May, according to people familiar with the figures.
item.dc:creator: James Herron

media:content.media:description: A drilling site near Almetyevsk, Russia.

item.title: Emerging-Market Assets Extend Gains as Korean Rally Continues
item.description: Emerging-market stocks rose for a third consecutive session, with South Korean assets extending their world-beating gains after a presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Andras Gergely

media:content.media:description: The rising Kospi and Korea Value-up indices displayed at the Korea Exchange in Seoul, on June 4.

item.title: Altimeter's Gerstner on the AI Arms Race and Investment
item.description: Venture capitalist, Altimeter Capital Founder & CEO and BG2 Podcast Host Brad Gerstner discusses the biggest challenges impacting tech, from America’s AI race with China to Silicon Valley’s growing influence in Washington with Bloomberg’s Emily Chang at Bloomberg Tech in San Francisco. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: McDonald’s Japan Sales Boosted By Minecraft, Chiikawa Crazes
item.description: McDonald’s Holdings Co. Japan saw a sales surge in May, helped by Happy Meal toys linked to two global crazes — the Minecraft movie and beloved character franchise Chiikawa.
item.dc:creator: Eddy Duan, Maho Nambu

media:content.media:description: A McDonald's Minecraft Movie Happy Meal box.

item.title: Oil Stalls as Traders Weigh Saudi Output Push, Summer Demand
item.description: Oil remained stuck near $65 a barrel as signs Saudi Arabia is seeking another big production increase at next month’s OPEC+ meeting offset the outlook for summer demand.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: A flame burns from a stack at the oil processing facility at Saudi Aramco's Shaybah oil field in the Rub' Al-Khali desert, also known as the 'Empty Quarter,' in Shaybah, Saudi Arabia, on Tuesday, Oct. 2, 2018. Saudi Arabia is seeking to transform its crude-dependent economy by developing new industries, and is pushing into petrochemicals as a way to earn more from its energy deposits. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

item.title: Panel Discusses Vital Role of The Group Chat in Tech
item.description: Hosts of the podcast, Great Chat, Ashley Mayer, Co-Founder & General Partner, Coalition Operators and Helen Min, Venture Partner, True Ventures discuss the role of group chats like WhatsApp, Signal, and iMessage in powering real-time collaboration in Silicon Valley with Bloomberg Beta’s Roy Bahat at Bloomberg Tech in San Francisco. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ‘So Bad It’s Good’: Buying Window Opens for Battered Small Caps
item.description: The smallest US stocks have entered a historically favorable time of year, boosting hopes that the beleaguered group can rebound after a dismal start to 2025.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

media:content.media:description: Small Size Consistently Outperforms in June

item.title: Indonesia Halts Nickel Mine Near Dive Hotspot on Tourism Concern
item.description: Indonesia will suspend production at a nickel mine near a diving hotspot in the east of the country over concerns it could impact tourism.
item.dc:creator: Eddie Spence, Eko Listiyorini

media:content.media:description: This photo taken on August 21, 2017 shows the blue sea around Raja Ampat -- which means Four Kings in Indonesian, in Indonesia's far eastern Papua. - Stretching across 67,000 square kilometres in Indonesias far east, the postcard-perfect islands might be about as close to paradise as visitors can find. (Photo by GOH CHAI HIN / AFP) / TO GO WITH Indonesia-Papua-environment-tourism-leisure,FEATURE by Kiki Siregar (Photo by GOH CHAI HIN/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: South Africa’s Current Account Deficit Narrows Slightly
item.description: South Africa’s current-account deficit narrowed slightly in the first quarter, beating expectations for it to widen.
item.dc:creator: Zinhle Xaba

media:content.media:description: Operations at the Port of Cape Town.

item.title: Meta’s Nuclear Deal Underscores the Looming Gap for AI’s Power Needs
item.description: Meta Platforms Inc.’s flashy deal this week for nuclear power was just the latest sign of the technology industry’s need for more energy — and fast. And while the top US reactor companies are eager to sign more contracts, the big question remains: Will new generation come online quickly enough?
item.dc:creator: Will Wade, Shoko Oda

media:content.media:description: The Clinton Power Station in Illinois.

item.title: US Health-Care Policy Makes Deals ‘Incredibly Hard’, Advent Says
item.description: Health-care policy in the US poses a challenge for investors, whereas there are areas of opportunity in the sector in Europe, according to John Maldonado, managing partner at Advent.
item.dc:creator: Kriti Gupta, Will Davies

media:content.media:description: John Maldonado Source: Bloomberg

item.title: Traders Flock to Niche Options Market to Bet on Crude Oil Glut
item.description: Investors have ramped up wagers in a relatively obscure corner of the oil market that OPEC+ output hikes will lead to an eventual glut toward the end of this year and into 2026.
item.dc:creator: David Marino, Alex Longley

item.title: UBS Asset Management Says Japan Should Stop Issuing Long Bonds to Halt Selloff
item.description: A veteran portfolio manager has some advice for Japan: To calm volatility in the country’s government bond market, stop issuing debt with maturities above 30 years.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Tajitsu

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 1. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged while pushing back the timing for when it expects to reach its inflation target amid intensified uncertainties due to US tariff measures.

item.title: Europe Set to Benefit as Deals Rotate Away From US: Advent
item.description: John Maldonado, managing partner at Advent International, discusses the private equity deals climate and says Europe is set to benefit as investment rotates away from the US. Advent has been busy in the region, with several deals signed or close to being finalized in recent weeks, Maldonado says. He speaks with Bloomberg's Kriti Gupta from the sidelines of the SuperReturn conference in Berlin. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: EU Gets Court Boost in Right to Retaliate Against Trump Tariffs
item.description: The European Union’s power to impose retaliatory tariffs on US goods and services won a legal boost from an adviser to the bloc’s top court, as the 27-member jurisdiction continues to spar with President Donald Trump over trade.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Stolton

media:content.media:description: Zippo lighters at the company's plant in Bradford, Pennsylvania, US.

item.title: Suzuki Drops on Report Rare Earths Curbs Hit Car Production
item.description: Suzuki Motor Corp. shares extended a slump after the automaker halted production of a popular car model, with local media reporting China’s export restrictions on rare earths are behind the disruption.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Takahashi

media:content.media:description: A Suzuki Swift Sport. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Builders Shed Jobs at Pace Seen After Global Financial Crisis
item.description: Payrolls in the UK construction industry shrank at a pace last seen in 2010, when excluding the pandemic, according to a survey that casts doubt over the Labour government’s ambition for a building boom.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: A construction worker on a residential site in London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Wizz Stock Plunges After Profit Misses Estimates, Costs Rise
item.description: Wizz Air Holdings Plc suffered the steepest stock drop in more than five years after the Hungarian discount airline reported earnings that missed estimates and refrained from providing a guidance, citing poor visibility.
item.dc:creator: Kate Duffy

media:content.media:description: A Wizz Air check in area at London Luton Airport.
